title: Integration Studio - Endpoint Management
content:
You can integrate Service Management with Endpoint Management. This integration enables you to import devices from Endpoint Management into the UCMDB and the SACM module. During the import, the system attempts to identify the device owner to assign it to the correct user in Service Management. The user in Service Management can then view all assigned devices in the Service Portal under My Services and Assets. 

Furthermore, configuration managers or administrators can run remote actions against the imported devices. For example, they can restart a device, lock it, or start a virus scan directly from the device record in Service Management.

When using remote actions to manage devices via Endpoint Management, it’s your responsibility to set the correct permissions in the Endpoint Management application to ensure the integration is not misused for harmful actions.

Supported use cases

  1. Import devices from Endpoint Management into Service Management, to manage them in Service Management and give end users the ability to see their devices in the self service portal
  2. Import bundles from Endpoint Management into Service Management, to be able to trigger software deployment from Service Management against the device in Endpoint Management
  3. Run remote actions, like refresh, lock, launchBundle, from Service Management against a device in Endpoint Management
The integration use cases outlined in this document are meant to inspire and guide your integration efforts. However, they should not be viewed as definitive or guaranteed solutions for your specific situation. These examples may not be applicable to your particular license edition.

Data integration flow 

Importing devices

The integration can be triggered via a scheduled or manual process in Integration Studio. In these scenarios, the following events occur:
  • Pulls devices from Endpoint Management
  • Prepares the data for Universal CMDB
  • Creates or updates the CIs in Universal CMDB
  • Through Native SACM, the CIs are then made available in the SACM module in Service Management.
The following diagram depicts how devices are imported:
The Endpoint Management API does not support importing only modified devices. Each time an import is performed, all devices are imported.

The following details are imported with the out-of-box scenarios:

    • Device basic details:
      • Bios details
      • Serial number
      • Processor family
      • Virtual device
      • Operating system vendor
      • Operating system family
      • Operating system description
      • Discovered model
      • Discovered vendor
      • Discovered OS build
      • Discovered OS version
      • Discovered OS name: ​
      • VMWare resource id
      • VMWare id
      • Memory size
      • Node role
      • Node family​​​
      • IMAI
      • Phone number
      • DNS  name
      • Vendor
      • Endpoint ID
    • Bios details
      • Bios uuid
      • Bios serial_number
      • Bios asset_tag
      • Bios source
      • Bios version
      • Bios date: 
    • IP address details
      • IP address
    • CPU details
      • CPU id
      • CPU vendor
      • CPU clock speed
      • Number of cores
      • CPU type
    • Owner (if identified in Service Management)
    The following details are not imported:
    • Hard Disk details
    • Network adapter details
    • Installed software on the device
    In case additional information are required to be imported, customer can adjust the integration templates.

    Importing bundles

    The integration can be triggered via a scheduled or manual process in Integration Studio. In this scenario, the following events occur:

    • Pulls bundles from Endpoint Management
    • Prepares the data for the Asset Models
    • Creates or updates the Asset Models in Service Management

    The following diagram depicts how bundles are imported:

    The Endpoint Management API currently does not support importing only new or modified bundles. Therefore, each time the import is run, all bundles will be imported.

    The following bundle details are imported:

    • Bundle ID
    • Bundle Name
    • Bundle Description
    • Bundle version

    Set up the integration

    The following procedure sets up the integration required to implement the described use cases. The integration process uses several templates, such as Endpoint Management – Import Devices. You can create a custom integration scenario based on this template and then adjust specific settings to customize the out-of-the-box scenarios to suit your requirements.

    Prerequisites

    This solution is designed and works with Service Management in the Native SACM context, especially when importing devices. If you do not have Native SACM deployed, this solution only creates CIs in UCMDB. 

    To set up the integration, make sure the following prerequisites are satisfied

    Network connectivity

    The Service Management system must be able to directly connect to the Endpoint Management system. The On-Premise-Bridge is not supported for the scenario template Endpoint Management – Import Devices.

    Endpoint Management Credentials

    Ensure you have the OAUTH2 client ID and client secret to connect to the Endpoint Management API.

    Configurations in UCMDB

    Go to the CI type manager in UCMDB, select CI type Node, and add a new field endpointmanagement_id of type string.

    Configurations in Service Management

    •  In Service Management, go to Administration -> Studio, and select the Device entity.
    • Create a new field EndpointManagementID of type SMALL_TEXT. Make it a federated field and select the EndpointManagement ID field created in UCMDB.
    • [Optional] Create a new field EndpointManagementURL of type URL.

    Prepare an integration user in Service Management

    Perform the following steps to prepare an integration user:

    1. Create an integration user. See How to create an integration user.

    2. Log in to the Agent Interface as the tenant admin.

    3. Navigate to Administration > Master Data > People, locate the integration user, and then assign the proper roles to access the SACM module.

      1. For Service Management, the role must have the necessary permissions to update Device records.

      2. To import bundles from Endpoint Management, ensure the role has permissions to create and update Asset Models.

        Alternatively, add the Tenant Admin role to grant general access.
         

      3. For UCMDB, specify a role that allows creating and updating CIs.

    Create endpoints

    The following section explains how to create endpoints for Endpoint Management and UCMDB.

    Endpoint Management

    Create an endpoint using the Rest Executor 2.0 endpoint type:

    1. Log in to the agent interface as the tenant admin.

    2. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Endpoints.

    3. Click Add.

    4. Select Rest Executor 2.0 as the endpoint type, enter a name for the endpoint (for example, Endpoint Management), and then click Add. The system creates the endpoint.

    5. Click Configure and follow the instructions provided in the following section.

    Use agentless endpoint

    To use an agentless endpoint, configure your Service Management instance to connect directly to the Endpoint Management API as documented here:

    Field Value
    General configuration
    Agent Select Agentless for a direct connection to the Graph API.
    Authentication type Select OAuth 2.0
    Protocol Select https.
    Base URL Enter the base URL of the Endpoint Management API: https://<FQDN Endpoint Management>.
    Certificate type Leave it empty.
    Certificate format Leave it empty.
    Server certificate Leave it empty.
    Enable email notification for expired token Optional
    Recipients Optional
    Get Token configuration
    Grant Type

    Client Credentials is designed for server-to-server communication. It connects to the specific app and uses the permissions assigned to the app.
    Client ID The application ID.
    Client Secret The secret key for the app.
    Redirect URL Automatically generated.
    Token URL The Endpoint Management OAUTH2 token URL.
    Scope otds:roles
    State
    Send client ID and secret In body
    Universal CMDB
    Create another endpoint for UCMDB. This second endpoint is required to create and update the CIs directly in UCMDB. 

    Configure the fields as shown in the following table:

    Field Value
    Agent Select Agentless for a direct connection to Universal CMDB.
    Authentication type

    Select Generic
    Protocol Select https.
    Base URL Enter the base URL of the Universal CMDB system: https://<FQDN>:<port>
    Authentication URL Enter the authentication URL. https://<FQDN>/ucmdb-server/rest-api/authenticate
    Certificate type optional
    Certificate format optional
    Server certificate optional
    Configure the Authentication request
    Encrypted data
    Parameter: userName
    Value: <login name of the integration user> 
    Parameter: password
    Value: <password of the integration user>
    Parameter: customerId
    Value: <the tenant Id/customer Id>
    Header Key: Content-Type
    Value: application/json
    Method POST
    Body

    Enter the JSON payload with user name and password:

    {
      "username": "${userName}",
      "password": "${password}",
      "repository": "UCMDB",
      "clientContext": ${customerId}
    }

    Note: ${userName}, ${password}, ${customerId} refers to the parameters in the encrypted data section

    Extract data from the authentication response
    Parameter HTTP Element Expression
    token

    Body

    		 $.token

    Configure headers and cookies for subsequent requests
    Parameter HTTP Element Expression
    Authorization Header

    Bearer ${token}

    Note: This is a reference to the token parameter in the Extract data from authentication response section

    Create an integration

    To create an integration based on the Microsoft Graph connector, follow these steps. 

    1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio. 

    2. Click New, enter the name of your integration, and then click Save. The system displays the Integration page.
    3. In the Details section, configure the integration user you created for the current Service Management system and activate the integration.
    4. In the Connector-Endpoint mappings section:
      1. Click Add to add a mapping -> Enter an alias for the mapping. For example, In the case of Endpoint Management, select Endpoint Management as the connector, and select the Endpoint Management endpoint you created earlier.
      2. Click Add another mapping -> Enter an alias for the mapping. For example: In the case of UCMDB, select Universal CMDB as the connector, and select the UCMDB endpoint you created earlier.
    5. Click Save. 

    Use the scenario to import devices

    Configure the scenario

    Perform the following steps to add and configure a scenario using the predefined template:

    1. Click Add scenario. 

    2. Enter a name for the scenario. For example, enter Endpoint Management – Import devices.

    3. In the Template field, select Endpoint Management – Import devices from the list. 

    4. Click Save to add the scenario. 

    5. Configure the parameters described in the following section, and then click Save.

    Parameters to consider before using the scenario

    In the Settings rule at the beginning of the process logic section, you can use the following parameters to control the scenario's behavior.

    Parameter Description
    sleepTimeInMinutes
    The time to wait in minutes to ensure that the CI added to UCMDB are synchronized to Service Management via the Native SACM functionality.
    Once this time has passed, the Service Management data can be enriched with the owner's information and the Endpoint Management URL of the device.
    keepNullValues If set to true, null values from Endpoint Management properties are retained as null and forwarded to the Universal CMDB, resulting in field values being left empty in the Universal CMDB.  If this value is set to false, the system will ignore null values and therefore will not update the field in Universal CMDB.
    enrichOTSMOwner If this parameter is set to true, the scenario is trying to find the owner of the Endpoint Management device in the Service Management database. If identified, the Owner property is populated with the user name.
    enrichOTSMDrilldownUrl
    If this parameter is set to true, the scenario adds a link to the Endpoint Management device to the device record in Service Management.
    By setting this to true, the custom property Endpoint ManagementURL must be available in the Device entity. (see prerequisites)
    EndpointManagementBaseURL
    The Endpoint Management base URL. 
    This parameter is required when the parameter enrichOTSMDrilldownUrl is set to true.
    EndpointManagementUrlExtension The URL to navigate directly to the record.
    userIdentificationProperty
    Specifies which property in the Service Management Person entity is used to identify the user of the device.
    This parameter is required when the parameter enrichOTSMOwner is set to true.

    In the step Query parameters, define the initial parameters to influence the Endpoint Management response.

    Parameter Description
    size
    The number of records to fetch from Endpoint Management per call. 
    initialFields The initial fields to fetch when the list of devices is queried.
    page The starting page.
    final The final query parameters for the execution of the request.

    Run the scenario

    To run the scenario, create a scheduler in Integration Studio that imports all devices from Endpoint Management on a regular basis.

    Additional information

    If the custom properties are named differently from what is documented here, adjust the scenario according to the following steps:

    1. endpointmanagement_id (created in UCMDB)
      1. This property is used in step 3 - Runtime data.
      2. Go to the key node template, and modify the property name in the value column associated with that key.
    2. EndpointManagement_URL (created in Service Management)
      1. This property is used in step 31 - Service Management Update device record.
      2. In the payload section, please ensure that you adjust the field name as needed.

    Use the scenario to import bundles

    Configure the scenario

    Perform the following steps to add and configure a scenario using the predefined template:

    1. Click Add scenario. 

    2. Enter a name for the scenario. For example, enter Endpoint Management – Import bundles.

    3. In the Template field, select Endpoint Management – Import bundles from the list. 

    4. Click Save to add the scenario. 

    5. Configure the parameters described in the following section, and then click Save.

    Parameters to consider before using the scenario

    In the Settings rule at the beginning of the process logic section, you can use the following parameters to control the scenario's behavior.

    Parameter Description
    ParentAssetModel
    The parent Asset Model as category where all the imported bundles are added as child models.
    ModelType The type of the Asset Model to use.

    In the step Query parameters, define the initial parameters to influence the Endpoint Management response.

    Parameter Description
    size
    The number of records to fetch from Endpoint Management per call. 
    page The starting page.
    final The final query parameters for the execution of the request.

    Run the scenario

    To run the scenario, create a scheduler in Integration Studio that imports all bundles from Endpoint Management on a regular basis.

    Additional information

    The ID of the bundle is stored in the ExternalRefence property of the Asset Model entity.

    Use the scenario to run remote actions

    The Execute action scenario allows customers to run various actions against the devices in Endpoint Management. An action can restart a device, but also deploy new software packages or launch specific scripts.

    Perform the following steps to add and configure a scenario using the predefined template:

    1. Click Add scenario. 

    2. Enter a name for the scenario. For example, enter Endpoint Management – Execute action.

    3. In the Template field, select Endpoint Management – Execute action from the list. 

    4. Click Save to add the scenario. 

    5. Configure the parameters described in the following section, and then click Save.

    This template is preconfigured to run simple actions, such as refresh. Other remote actions from Endpoint Management may require changes in the payload sent to Endpoint Management to trigger the action correctly.

    Parameters to consider before using the scenario

    In the Settings rule at the beginning of the process logic section, you can use the following parameters to control the scenario's behavior.

    These parameters are typically sent from the calling application, such as an automated task or a business rule. See the following examples.

    Parameter Description
    Action
    The action to execute against the Endpoint Management device.
    Note: Some actions require different payloads. Please check Endpoint Management API description.
    User The Service Management username that triggered the integration.
    DeviceId The Endpoint Management device ID to run the remote action against.
    BundleId The Endpoint Management bundle ID to install a software bundle. Only required when the action launchBundle is triggered.
    FriendlyActionName (Optional) Provides the ability to convert the Endpoint Management remote action names into user friendly value.

    Run the scenario

    To run the scenario, two options are available.
    Run scenario by using a custom action
    Add a Custom Action
    1. Go to Service Management Studio and select the Device entity.
    2. Go to the Custom Actions tab.
    3. Create an Action group with the name Endpoint Management.
    4. Create a custom action.
      1. Name: EndpointManagementrefresh. (Ensure the action name is correctly spelled).
      2. Display name: Refresh.
      3. Enable workflow: true.
      4. Select an icon.
      5. Position in record page: Show as primary.
      6. Group in record page: Select your Action Group.
      7. Position in grid page: Do not show.
    5. Save the action
    Add a business rule to trigger the execution of the remote action when the custom action is clicked.
    1. Go to Service Management Studio and select the Device entity.
    2. Go to Processes and Rules tab.
    3. Go to After applying changes  section and add a new rule.
      1. Rule type: Call integration studio.
      2. Condition: indexof(entity.CustomActionName_c, 'EndpointManagement')==0 && current_update.CustomActionCount_c.IsChanged. Note that the rule is only triggered when the custom action name contains EndpointManagement.
      3. Integration: Select the integration.
      4. Scenario: Select the scenario. For example, Endpoint Management - Execute action.
      5. Payload: Add the following key / value pairs.
        Left column content 
        (key)
        		 Right column content (value) Description
        EndpointManagementId  fx: ${entity.EndpointManagementID_c}    The reference to the EndpointManagement ID field, created in the prerequisites section
        Action fx: ${substring(entity.CustomActionName_c,8,length(entity.CustomActionName_c))} The expression will extract the Endpoint Management action name from the custom action name. For example, refresh in the custom action created above.
        User fx: {current_user.Name} The name of the user who triggered the action
    Those keys and their values are passed to the integration studio scenario for usage in the scenario.
    Once the custom action and business rule are added, go to the Device records imported by the Endpoint Management - Import Devices scenario and click the custom action to trigger the remote action in Endpoint Management.
    Deploy a software bundle from a service catalog offering via task plan

    It is possible to run the remote actions from the task plan of an offering. For example, to trigger the installation of a software bundle. To implement this example, complete the following steps.

    Create a service offering

    • General tab - example data
      • Title & Description: "Install Adobe Acrobat Reader" with the following 
      • Status: Active
      • Required Asset Information: Device
      • Offered Asset Model: Select a record from the imported Endpoint Management bundles. For example: Adobe Acrobat Reader
    • Default values tab
      • Select a service, an impact, an urgency, a service desk group, an owner and a category
      • By selecting those values, the request enters the fulfillment phase automatically
    • Task plan tab
      • Select the Fulfill tab
      • Create a new automated task
        • Give the task a title, description and set an assignment group
        • Add a business rule of type Call Integration Studio
        • Select the Endpoint Management integration and the Endpoint Management - Execute action scenario
        • In the Payload (optional) parameter, enter the following values. These details are passed to the scenario.
          Left column content 
          (key)
          		 Right column content (value) Description
          Action launchBundle The Endpoint Management action to run. 
          EndpointManagementId fx: ${entity.RegisteredForDevice.EndpointManagementID_c} The reference to the EndpointManagement ID field, created in the prerequisites section
          BundleId fx: ${entity.RequestsOffering.ComposedByAssetModel.ExternalReference} The reference to the Bundle ID field in the Asset Model. The Bundle ID is stored in the ExternalRefernce  field.
          User fx: ${current_user.Name} The name of the user who triggered the action

    With such an offering, an end user can request Adobe Acrobat Reader from the Self Service Portal. The system will automatically start the fulfillment of the request. If the deployment was successful, the request is automatically moved to the Accept phase.
